titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Newbold Morris 1962 storm response papers 1978.001
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-01-05 19:54:30 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Newbold Morris 1962 storm response papers document New York City and State official response to a severe late winter storm in 1962 that caused considerable damage to property along the Long Island shorefront.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The papers were formally accessioned in 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Newbold Morris (1902-1966) succeeded Robert Moses as Parks Commissioner of the City of New York in 1960. During his career Morris also served as President of the New York City Council and ran unsuccessfully for mayor of New York City twice.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Newbold Morris 1962 storm response papers, 1978.001, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024. At that time, the collection was renamed from Newbold Morris papers to Newbold Morris 1962 storm response papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Newbold Morris 1962 storm response papers document New York City and State official response to a severe late winter storm in 1962 that caused considerable damage to property along the Long Island shorefront. The predominant community represented in the collection is Fire Island, but also included are Shirley, Bayshore, Babylon, and the Rockaways. The collection contains photocopies of clippings from several New York City and Long Island newspapers, photographs, hand-drawn diagrams, and a copy of an act to form a commission to study the property damages and make recommendations for the restoration and protection of the affected area. The committee was dubbed the Temporary State Commission on Protection and Preservation of the Atlantic Shorefront, and its members included Joseph F. Carlino, Chairman, H. Lee Dennison, Vice Chairman, and Robert Moses, Secretary.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
